questions.question: About cleft palate all are correct EXCEPT:
options: Usually associated with other congenital anomalies.
May range from cleft uvula up to tripartite deformity.
Best time for repair is 5 years old.
questions.explanation: Optimal repair is 6-12 months (before 18 months) for speech development. Waiting until 5 years is too late as speech patterns are already established.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: About cleft upper lip all are correct EXCEPT:
options: Lateral is due to non-fusion of median nasal process (future frenulum) with maxillary process.
Lateral is more common on left side.
Best time for repair is the earliest possible time (3 months).
Repair is mainly for cosmetic purposes.
questions.explanation: Unilateral cleft lip (specifically on the left side) is the most common presentation. Median cleft lip is extremely rare and is often associated with holoprosencephaly.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All the followings are presentations of cancer tongue:
questions.explanation: Presentations include painless ulcer, referred otalgia (via CN IX), induration/fissuring, or halitosis due to necrosis. All options are correct.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Carcinoma of the tongue infiltrating the mandible is best treated by:
options: Radiotherapy of both primary and regional gland.
Two-stage excision of primary and regional glands.
Monoblock excision of primary and whole lymphatic area (Commando operation).
Radiotherapy for primary followed by radical neck dissection.
Excision of primary and radiotherapy to cervical lymph nodes.
questions.explanation: Mandibular involvement requires a 'Commando operation' (Composite Resection): monoblock excision of the primary tumor, mandibular segment, and neck dissection.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Concerning complete cleft palate, the untrue statement is that it:
options: Due to failed fusion of palatal shelves with each other and frontonasal process.
Is often associated with cleft-lip and broadening of the face.
Predisposes to upper respiratory tract infections.
Requires surgical repair after the second year of life.
questions.explanation: Cleft palate repair is generally performed around 9-12 months of age. Waiting until after the second year is detrimental to speech development; early repair is preferred.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Concerning fibrous epulis the incorrect statement is that it:
options: Is a soft fibroma of the mucoperiosteum around a carious tooth.
Forms a small pedunculated swelling arising between two incisor teeth.
May be highly vascular or fibrous.
questions.explanation: Simple excision is insufficient as it arises from periodontal ligament. Treatment requires excision with periosteum and extraction/scaling of the tooth to prevent recurrence.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Correct statements about dentigerous cyst include the following EXCEPT that it:
options: Occurs in children and adolescents in relation to a missing tooth.
Is more common in the upper than in the lower jaw.
Presents as a globular swelling expanding the jaw.
questions.explanation: Dentigerous cysts are most commonly associated with impacted third molars in the mandible (lower jaw), not the upper jaw.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Dental ulcer is characterized by the following features EXCEPT that it:
options: Occurs in relation to a carious or irregular tooth.
Has an elongated shallow floor and a sloping edge.
Never causes enlargement of the regional lymph nodes.
questions.explanation: Dental ulcers are inflammatory/infective lesions and can definitely cause reactive enlargement of regional lymph nodes (lymphadenitis).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In unilateral harelip the following statements are true EXCEPT that it:
options: Due to failed fusion of maxillary process with frontonasal process.
Is always associated with nasal deformity.
questions.explanation: Cleft lip affects labial sounds (p, b, m) and often involves alveolar clefts impacting articulation. It causes speech defects, so 'no serious defects' is false.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Langen beek's repair:
options: Is a method of grafting in burns
Is a method of repair after surgical excision of SCC
Is a method of repair of cleft lip
Is a method of repair of cleft palate
questions.explanation: Von Langenbeck's technique is a classical surgical method used for the repair of cleft palate (palatoplasty).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The wrong statement about carcinoma of the lip is that it:
options: Affects males much more often than females.
Usually occurs on the lower lip.
May produce a Kissing cancer on the other lip.
Is most often a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma.
Spreads to the regional glands by lymphatic permeation.
questions.explanation: SCC classically affects the lower lip. The key marks this 'wrong', likely confusing it with BCC (upper lip) or suggesting it's not 'usually' there.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A paraplegic bed-ridden patient developed a large deep bed-sore over his sacrum. The best regimen is by wide excision and:
questions.explanation: Deep sacral sores have dead space and exposed bone. A myocutaneous flap provides necessary bulk and blood supply to fill the defect and cushion the area.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A subtype of capillary hemangioma raised above skin surface:
questions.explanation: Strawberry hemangiomas (infantile hemangiomas) present as raised, red, lobulated masses. Port-wine stains and salmon patches are flat, macular vascular malformations.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: About healing intentions:
options: Second intention gives better cosmoses than first.
First intention occurs on clean cut edges without gaps or tissue loss.
questions.explanation: Healing by first intention (primary intention) occurs when wound edges are clean and approximated (e.g., sutured incision), resulting in minimal scarring. Ulcers heal by secondary intention.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: About management of burns:
options: Biological dressing decreases all complications of burn.
Parkland's formula is a good rule for fluid replacement.
Occlusive dressing is easier to perform.
Exposure method is suitable for face and buttocks.
questions.explanation: Parkland formula guides fluids, occlusive dressings reduce pain, and exposure suits the face. All listed principles are correct in burn management.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: First-intention healing of clean incised wounds is characterized by the following EXCEPT:
options: An inflammatory reaction during the first few days.
Fibroblastic proliferation and capillary budding during the next week.
Region of normal tensile strength within 4 weeks.
questions.explanation: Wounds do not regain normal (100%) tensile strength in 4 weeks. Strength increases gradually, reaching about 20% at 3 weeks and plateauing at roughly 80% after several months.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Metabolic changes after burning are due to the following except:
options: Local fluid loss into the burnt area.
questions.explanation: Burns cause a significant loss of skin barrier function, leading to massive evaporative water loss and increased heat loss, driving a hypermetabolic state (not reduced heat loss).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most common site for the following diseases is correctly matched EXCEPT:
options: Keloids: face, neck, and skin over sternum.
questions.explanation: Hypertrophic scars are common on flexor surfaces or tension areas. Matching them with extensor surfaces is incorrect compared to the other options.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Wound healing is not impaired by:
questions.explanation: Mild/moderate anemia doesn't significantly impair healing if volume/oxygenation are adequate. Hypoproteinemia and steroids have a direct negative impact.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: About 3rd degree (full thickness) burn:
questions.explanation: Full-thickness (3rd degree) burns involve necrosis of the entire skin thickness. The tissue (eschar) typically appears dry, leathery, white, or charred (black) and is insensate.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In the rule of nines:
questions.explanation: In the standard adult Rule of Nines, each lower limb represents 18% of the total body surface area (TBSA). Head is 9%, Arm is 9%, Front trunk is 18%.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most frequent fracture of the face involves the:
questions.explanation: The mandible is often cited as the most frequently fractured facial bone (excluding nasal bones in some lists) due to its prominence and vulnerability.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most useful measure in preventing renal shut-down in post burn patient is:
options: Monitoring an hourly urine output between 30 and 50 ml
questions.explanation: Maintaining adequate renal perfusion is key to preventing renal failure. This is best monitored by ensuring an hourly urine output of 0.5-1 ml/kg/hr (approx 30-50 ml/hr in adults).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All the followings are predisposing factors for cancer tongue except:
questions.explanation: The '5 Ss' of tongue cancer risk are: Smoking, Spirits (alcohol), Spices, Sepsis (dental), and Syphilis. Sjogren's syndrome is not a standard risk factor for SCC of the tongue.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 6y boy has a 2cm pulsatile lesion on the right cheek, enhancing since birth, with a thrill and harsh bruit. It has multiple feeding arteries. What is the best treatment option?
questions.explanation: The description fits a high-flow Arteriovenous Malformation (pulsatile, thrill). The standard management is angio-embolization to reduce vascularity followed by surgical excision.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Fastest promoter of epithelization in wound healing occurs with:
questions.explanation: Occlusive dressings maintain a moist wound environment, which facilitates faster migration of epithelial cells across the wound bed compared to a dry environment (scab).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In unilateral harelip, the following statements are true EXCEPT that it:
options: Due to failed fusion of maxillary process with fronto-nasal process.
Is always associated with nasal deformity.
questions.explanation: Cleft lip affects labial sounds and is often linked to alveolar clefts causing articulation issues. Thus, 'no serious speech defects' is the false statement.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following are subtypes of capillary hemangioma EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Cirsoid aneurysm is an arteriovenous fistula/malformation, distinct from capillary hemangiomas or malformations like Strawberry hemangioma or Port-wine stain.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The repair of cleft lip should be done at which age:
questions.explanation: Cleft lip is typically repaired around 3 months of age, often following the 'Rule of 10s' (10 weeks old, 10 lbs weight, 10g Hb).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The main advantage of Lund and Browder charts over rule of nines is:
options: More accurate regarding sex of patient.
More accurate regarding age of patient.
questions.explanation: Lund and Browder charts account for changing body proportions (e.g., large head in children), making them more accurate than the Rule of Nines for pediatrics.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most frequent gastrointestinal complication of an extensive burn is:
questions.explanation: Acute gastric dilatation/paralytic ileus is a very common early complication. While Curling's ulcer is specific to burns, dilation is frequently cited as most common.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following is not true about keloids?
options: Keloid is excessive scar formation within and outside the boundaries of skin incision.
Recurrence rate of keloid after excision is 10-20%.
Exact cause of keloid formation is not known but fibroblast dysfunction is commonly attributed.
Adjunctive treatment besides surgery gives the best results.
questions.explanation: The recurrence rate of keloids after simple excision alone is very high (50-80% or more). A rate of 10-20% is incorrect unless adjuvant therapy (like steroids or radiation) is used.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following is true about Langer's line of the skin?
options: These are in the direction of muscle fibers.
These are perpendicular to the long axis of underlying muscle fibers.
Most favorable incision is circular over an exposed area.
Most favorable incision is a rhomboid shaped one over an exposed area.
questions.explanation: Langer's lines (relaxed skin tension lines) run parallel to skin creases, which are formed perpendicular to the direction of the underlying muscle contraction.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A case presented by chronic ulcer resistant for healing, the following support your diagnosis as basal cell carcinoma except:
questions.explanation: A chronic, non-healing ulcer on the face of a middle-aged male is highly suspicious for malignancy (BCC). The decision to 'conserve' (observe) is inappropriate; biopsy or excision is required.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All of the following are signs of epitheliomatous transformation in basal cell carcinoma except:
questions.explanation: Basement membrane invasion defines carcinoma, not transformation. Rapid growth, everted edges, and LN involvement indicate aggressive behavior or SCC transformation.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Amelanotic melanoma is differentiated from SCC by:
options: Can not be differentiated except after excision
questions.explanation: DOPA reaction detects tyrosinase in melanocytes. Amelanotic melanomas still contain this enzyme despite lacking pigment, differentiating them from SCC.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Concerning basal-cell carcinomas, the false statement is that they are:
options: Much less common than squamous cell carcinomas.
Very rare in oriental and black races.
Histologically: dark-staining solid masses of cells from the basal layer.
Commonest on the exposed skin of blonde subjects and outdoor workers.
questions.explanation: Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) is the most common form of skin cancer, significantly more common than Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Contraindications to irradiation in skin malignancy include the following except:
options: Lesions in upper half of face
questions.explanation: Old age is not a contraindication; radiotherapy is often preferred in elderly poor surgical candidates. Recurrence and deep invasion are contraindications.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In Parkland's formula, the initial fluid replacement in 1st day is:
options: Blood + Normal saline guided by hematocrete value
questions.explanation: The Parkland formula mandates the use of crystalloids, specifically Ringer's Lactate, for volume resuscitation in the first 24 hours post-burn.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Malignant melanoma is characterized by the following except:
options: Is rare in the black races.
Carries the worst prognosis when arising in the head, neck or trunk.
questions.explanation: Malignant melanoma is traditionally considered radio-resistant, and surgery is the primary treatment modality.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Risk factors for malignant transformation in naevi include the following except:
questions.explanation: Lentigo (simple lentigo) is a benign pigmented spot and is generally not considered a high-risk precursor for malignant transformation compared to junctional activity or chronic irritation.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Surgical excision in malignant melanoma:
options: Is performed only in inoperable case
Is advisable whatever the stage and type
There is no need for surgical excision of LNs
questions.explanation: Wide surgical excision is the cornerstone of melanoma treatment for all stages (curative for early stages, palliative for advanced/metastatic).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The best prognostic plastic factor in malignant melaonoma is:
questions.explanation: Breslow thickness (measured in millimeters) is the single most important prognostic factor for localized malignant melanoma.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following (are) is correct about incidence of malignant melanoma:
options: The most common type is the superficial spreading one
Very rare to occur on top of benign mealonma
questions.explanation: Superficial Spreading Melanoma is the most common subtype, accounting for approximately 70% of all melanoma cases.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following about squamous cell carcinoma is untrue:
options: Xeroderma pigmentosa is a recognized risk factor
SCC occurs in sun exposure areas
SSS is called marjolin's ulcer when it occurs in chronic ulcers
It can give distant metastasis in contrary to BCC
questions.explanation: All the listed statements are true: Xeroderma and sun exposure are risk factors, Marjolin's ulcer is an SCC arising in a chronic wound, and SCC has metastatic potential (unlike BCC).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following are (is) correctly matched about origin of skin tumors:
options: Basal cell carcinoma → Basal areas or appendages
questions.explanation: Squamous Cell Carcinoma arises from keratinocytes in the epidermis, Basal Cell Carcinoma from the basal layer or hair follicles, and Melanoma from melanocytes. All matches are correct.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following are (is) incorrectly matched about behavior of skin tumors:
options: Basal cell carcinoma locally malignant tumor
questions.explanation: Malignant melanoma is an aggressive tumor with a high propensity for distant metastasis; describing it merely as 'locally malignant' (like BCC) is incorrect.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following are type of subtypes of capillary hemangioma except:
questions.explanation: Cirsoid aneurysm is a form of arteriovenous malformation, not a capillary hemangioma.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following statements about bedsores (Decubitus ulcers) are correct except:
options: Usually involve pressure points on the back.
Result from pressure ischemia and sloughing.
Never penetrate deeply to involve muscle and bone.
Are preventable by proper nursing care.
questions.explanation: Advanced pressure sores (Stage IV) frequently penetrate deeply, involving muscle, tendon, and bone, leading to osteomyelitis.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The following type of malignant melanoma has the best prognosis:
questions.explanation: Superficial Spreading Melanoma has a better prognosis due to a prolonged radial growth phase before vertical invasion compared to nodular types.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The main advantage of Lund and Browder charts overrule of nines is:
options: More accurate to regarding sex of patient
More accurate regarding age of patient
questions.explanation: Lund and Browder charts provide age-specific adjustments for body surface area percentages, making them more accurate than the Rule of Nines, especially for children.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most characteristic histopathological finding in basal cell carcinoma is:
questions.explanation: Histologically, BCC is characterized by nests of basaloid cells with peripheral 'palisading' (cells aligned in a parallel fence-like manner at the edge).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most common type of basal cell carcinoma is:
questions.explanation: The Nodulo-ulcerative type, clinically referred to as a Rodent Ulcer, is the most common variant of Basal Cell Carcinoma.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most frequent gastrointestinal complication of an extensive burn is:
questions.explanation: Acute gastric dilatation/ileus is a very common early complication in extensive burns. (Note: Curling's ulcer is specific but often less frequent than simple ileus/dilation in the acute phase).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The prognosis of patients with malignant melanoma depends on:
questions.explanation: Prognosis is determined by tumor thickness (Breslow depth), stage (presence of nodal or distant metastasis), and anatomical location (BANS areas - Back, Arm, Neck, Scalp - often have worse outcomes).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which statement is incorrect concerning rodent ulcer?
options: Have a red granular floor and a rolled-in beaded edge.
May spread to regional lymph nodes.
Is best treated by surgical excision.
questions.explanation: Rodent ulcer (BCC) is locally invasive but does not metastasize to regional lymph nodes (incidence is < 0.1%).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which statement is incorrect concerning varicose ulcers?
options: Are always chronic and often recurrent.
Occur most often on the medial aspect of the lower third of the leg.
Are always associated with superficial varicosities.
Are often surrounded by an area of induration, pigmentation, edema and dermatitis.
questions.explanation: Venous ulcers result from deep venous hypertension. Visible superficial varicosities may be absent if the issue is deep venous incompetence.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which statement is untrue concerning malignant melanoma?
options: Is common in children, negroes, and Asians.
Usually occurs between the ages of 50 and 60 years.
May arise do novo or in a benign pigmented naevus.
questions.explanation: Malignant melanoma is rare in children and significantly less common in darker-skinned populations (Negroes/Asians) compared to fair-skinned individuals.
questions.subject: General Surgery
